title: 111_hr3737
content: The "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" allows intermediaries to report borrower information to credit agencies for credit building. It also provides flexibility in credit terms. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from certain paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require individuals involved in making microloans to have specific experience and qualifications, including at least 1 year of experience making microloans or having a full-time employee with 3 years of experience in this area. Additionally, they must have experience providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance as part of their microloan program. The Small Business Act now mandates individuals involved in making microloans to have 1 year of experience providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers as part of the microloan program. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing to $1,000,000 and $7,000,000, with the option to treat it as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance to 35 percent. SEC. 7 introduces the Young Entrepreneurs Program. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program, allowing intermediaries to provide technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing small businesses and securing financing. The Young Entrepreneurs Program allows intermediaries to provide technical assistance to individuals aged 25 or younger who have resided in the area for at least 2 years. Young entrepreneurs receiving assistance must make a good faith effort to establish or operate their small business in the same geographic area. The Young Entrepreneurs Program allows intermediaries to provide technical assistance to individuals aged 25 or younger who have resided in the area for at least 2 years. Young entrepreneurs can defer loan repayment for up to 6 months after receiving the final disbursement. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000 in various paragraphs. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the microloan program. The Administrator must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business, detailing the names and locations of intermediaries receiving funds, loan and grant amounts, contributions from non-Federal sources, and the number and amounts of microloans provided. The report required for the microloan program under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act includes details on the number and amounts of microloans made by intermediaries to various groups such as women entrepreneurs, low-income entrepreneurs, veteran entrepreneurs, disabled entrepreneurs, and minority entrepreneurs. It also includes information on the marketing, management, and technical assistance provided to these groups by the intermediaries. The report for the microloan program includes details on loans made to women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs. It also covers job creation, repayment history, and business success after receiving microloans. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under the Small Business Act. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 for Small Business Act programs, including technical assistance grants, direct loans, and interest assistance grants. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to implement its provisions.
